1114207419750469632.text:
All the women in the room had different stories to tell. Some grew up privileged, some grew up homeless. We all start somewhere. We're all learning.

But something really fucking special about women is that we mentor, give back, and lift others up. We rock.

Thanks @FBombBClub!

1114207419159044096.text:
Women and money:
-We often think we don't deserve as much as someone else. Don't think that way! You are your biggest stakeholder. Ask for what you deserve, and more.
-Money = air. It's an unlimited resource. Always ask for more.

@FBombBClub

1114207418571874304.text:
Money tips:
-Pick a day of the week to check your bank account. Make it relaxing. Grab some wine (I like to call this: wine-nancials). Or tea!
-Set up savings accounts for different purpose (i.e. emergency, retirement, treat yo' self funds)
-Automate your savings

@FBombBClub

1114207417988861952.text:
Misconceptions about money:
-"I can start saving...later...". No. Start now.
-"I don't have money to save..". No. Every little bit helps.
-"I need to be an expert in finance to make money." No. You just need to know the basics.

@FBombBClub

1114207416915070976.text:
For those who didn't go, here are key takeaways I wrote down on the topic of women, entrepreneurship, & money:

-Be okay with not knowing shit about money. Be open to learn. Everyone starts somewhere.
-You are your biggest stakeholder. Always advocate for yourself.
-Money = Power

AHH Jude Dai is dropping serious wisdom about anthropology and #VR:

Leverage what's natural for humans as you create, but also experiment with what new things we can enable humans to do. 

I WISH JUDE WAS ON TWITTER so I could tag her. Go follow @ImmersiveSquare, her company

1108562301060182016.text: @MXTreality is doing interesting experiments with #VR accessibility. I want to learn more!

1108562079298940928.text:
Jude made an especially good comment, which I'll paraphrase:

"While #VR may *help* us be more aware of bias, it won't solve it, and we still have a lot of work to do as individuals outside the headset."

VR is a tool, not an all-in-one solution. Thank you Jude

1108561494424182785.text:
There was a comment on the panel that VR has no bias...

Thank you @welkhoff and Jude Dai (Founder of @ImmersiveSquare) for stepping up to say there *is* bias in teams and experiences, and we have to work hard to make it more equitable, accessible, and make leadership diverse.

1108555227144183810.text:

1078734378321076224.text: I brought my Oculus but there were problems with setup taking way too long to fix, so I just didn't set up VR. Honestly, I'm glad I didn't. Doing face-to-face activities with my young cousins was so special. I'll never forget those moments. Legos, hide-and-seek, dominoes. So fun.

1078732248218710016.text: Spending time with family this holiday season (the first time we were all together!) made me realize how quickly time passes, how fast we grow. I want to be part of their lives as much as I can, and not let work be in the way. My work is not my life.

I used to think I had to go walk outside to think through the problem I'm facing.

But honestly I've found that *not* thinking about it forces me to be more present wherever I am. 

That information I take in somehow makes me feel more whole and connected. Not stuck in a bubble.

1060619661014790144.text:
Here's one of my favorite places to go to shut my brain off and just sit there.

Listen to the sounds of birds and cars. Count the clouds. Pet the doggos that walk by.pic.twitter.com/rwbVBbjoqh

1060618726331027457.text:
When I feel stuck while working, I go outside, shut my brain off, and walk. Touch plants. Pet doggos. Find a nice view and sit there for a bit. 

Once I'm back at my laptop I feel ready to rethink things.

It's amazing how much being present in the outdoors resets our brains.

1050276375125323778.text:
Mental health comes first, and I didn't *truly* understand that till 2018. 

I'm not giving up on #VR/#AR because of burnout, but I am re-framing how I approach it so it's healthier for myself and the people around me.

1050276374122909701.text:
In emerging industries like VR/AR, we share the responsibility to build a better future. And I believe we can.

To do that, we have to be willing to take a step back. We have the time to make this right.

1050276372596154369.text:
I am excited to step back on the train feeling focused and aligned with my values. 

I still have plenty of work to do, but taking care of myself this year has been the best possible thing I could do to see things from a fresh perspective.

1050276371396669441.text:
The tech industry in particular moves fast, which makes it hard as individuals to step back and reflect. 

But remember, slowing down isn't the same as stopping. 

You can always hop back on the train. It won't take off without you!

1050276370134138880.text:
If you feel overwhelmed, taking a step back−even in small ways−works wonders!

That could mean reading a book about a subject you know nothing about, disconnecting from screens, picking up a hobby. Things that help you feel connected to yourself and the world you live in.

1050275678648590336.text:
Taking a step back from the noise has helped me see more clearly than ever before, on both professional and personal levels. 

I feel more creative and energized because I have a better idea of what makes *me* motivated, instead of what *hype* tells me I should be excited about.

1050275676891181056.text:
We have so much power and responsibility in this industry. 

We have to make it a habit to get out of our bubbles, talk to minds different than ours, and bring them into our community early on. We know this.

But I couldn't do this easily when I was moving so fast all the time.

1050275675913908224.text:
So, I did!

My goal this year is to step back, slow down, and ask myself "why am I pursuing this? What do I want to accomplish? What do I want to learn?" All with the intent to rekindle my passion.

More so, I want to break out of the tech bubble I feel trapped in.

1050275674320076800.text:
I realized that my constant "go, go, go!" spirit hindered me from taking time to ask myself how I was doing. And worse, how my friends were doing. 

I lost touch with *why* I was doing all this work in the first place.

That's when I knew I needed to sloooooooow down.

1050275673300860933.text:
I thought I'd find my passion by doing a bunch of things related to my field: attend all the tech conferences and events, organize Meetups, speak on panels, talk about VR/AR with *any* stranger. 

But I hit a point where everything felt a bit...pointless.

1050275671736430592.text: Last year I experienced burnout for the first time. I didn't anticipate it would actually happen, so I kept working, late into the nights and weekends.
